miniChemistry.Utilities package¶

Submodules¶

miniChemistry.Utilities.Checks module¶

miniChemistry.Utilities.Checks.charge_check(charge: list | tuple, neutrality: bool, raise_exception: bool = True) → bool¶

Checks if the total charge passed to a function is (not) zero.

Parameters:

  • charge – a list or tuple of integers that indicate charges.

  • neutrality – True if charge must be equal to zero and False if not.

  • raise_exception – True if exception is to be raised if the test is failed.

Returns:

Boolean of exception describing if the charge is according to expectations (“neutrality” parameter).

miniChemistry.Utilities.Checks.keywords_check(keywords: list | tuple, allowed_keywords: list | tuple, function_name: str, variables: dict, raise_exception: bool = True) → bool¶

Checks if the keywords passed to a function are within the allowed keywords.

Parameters:

  • keywords – keywords to check. Usually **kwargs.

  • allowed_keywords – A list or tuple of allowed keywords.

  • function_name – Name of a function that called the keywords_check(). Used in exception calls.

  • variables – locals() from the function that called the keywords_check().

  • raise_exception – True if exception is to be raised if the test failed.

Returns:

miniChemistry.Utilities.Checks.single_element_cation_check(composition: Dict[Any, int], charge: int, raise_exception: bool = False) → bool¶

Checks if a cation passed to a function contains one element. The function is used in Particle class to check ALL substances. Hence, we have if charge > 0: else: return True. This line ensures that if a particle checked is NOT a cation at all, the test is passed.

Parameters:

  • composition – composition of a cation. Can be obtained from ion.composition.

  • charge – charge of a cation.

  • raise_exception – True if exception is to be raised if test failed.

Returns:

boolean or exception on whether a particle passed is a single-element cation.

miniChemistry.Utilities.Checks.type_check(parameters: list, types: list, strict_order: bool = False, raise_exception: bool = False) → bool¶

To be used in any case when the decorator cannot be used. For example, if a function accepts *args and **kwargs, you cannot set the types, so you have to check them manually.

Parameters:

  • parameters – list of parameters of a function.

  • types – list of types that each parameter can be.

  • strict_order – if True, then each parameter in “parameters” is matched to a type in “types” according to their

position in a list (i.e. type_check([a, b, c, d], [str, int, str, int], strict_order=True) means that we check for type(a) == str, type(b) == int, type(c) == str, and type(d) == int. If strict_order=False, we check for isinstance(a, (str, int)), same for all other parameters. :param raise_exception: True if exception is to be raised if the test failed. :return: Boolean or exception indicating if the type check is passed.

miniChemistry.Utilities.File module¶

This class is defined to handle simple operations on small text files. NOTE: the files should not be large, because the program loads all the content of a file at once and then treats it as a list. Primary purpose of this class then is to keep lists that the code will use separately, and away from the real code. This makes it easier to edit the lists as they might need to be updated. The class has a couple of tests (private methods that returns True/False or raise exception) that are used in many other methods, and one private method that is called to run these tests (see the class). The class implements simple operations on files as well as lists (because the content of the file is treated just as a list of strings).

NOTE: before working with the file, it is necessary to call .bind() method to either create a file or to connect to it.

class miniChemistry.Utilities.File.File(caller: str = '/Users/antonkutuzov/PycharmProjects/miniChemistryProject/miniChemistry/Utilities/File.py', splitter: str = '\n')¶

Bases: object

append(text: str, add_splitter: bool = True) → None¶

Appends a given string (parameter “text”) to the existing (bound) file.

Parameters:

  • text – string to be appended to the file

  • add_splitter – True is the splitter has to be added after the text. True by default

Returns:

bind(file_name: str) → None¶

Assigns a variable self._file a value of type Path. The path for the file is composed from the caller’s path, plus the name of the file. In the case the file does not exist, it will be created, in the case the file exists, it will be assigned to the self._file variable. NOTE: include the file extension in the file name. Not testfile, but testfile.txt!

Parameters:

file_name – name of the file, including extension (.txt)

Returns:

property caller: Path¶
property caller_directory: Path¶
property caller_name: str¶
delete() → None¶

Deletes the file

erase_all() → None¶

Just erases all the text from the file

erase_index(index: int) → str¶

Erases a string located at a certain position.

Parameters:

index – position where the string must be erased

Returns:

erased string

erase_text(text: str) → None¶

Removes a string passed as a “text” parameter from the file. Does not support string sequences, connected by self.splitter. This method removes ALL occurrences of the string from the file.

Parameters:

text – string that has to be removed from the file

Returns:

find(text: str) → bool¶

Checks if a given string is present in the file. Works also for sequences, connected by self.splitter.

Parameters:

text – string for which the file is checked

Returns:

index(text: str) → int¶

Searches for the position of the string given in the “text” parameter. Returns the smallest index (first occurrence). For all occurrences, use self.positions(). NOTE: unlike .find(), this method does not support search for sequences of strings connected with self.splitter

Parameters:

text – string which position must be found

Returns:

position of the first occurrence of the string in the file

property is_empty: bool¶
property name: str¶
property path: Path¶
positions(text: str) → List[int]¶

Searches for ALL occurrences of the string passed as the “text” parameter. Returns a list of the indices (ints). NOTE: unlike .find(), this method does not support search for sequences of strings connected with self.splitter

Parameters:

text – string which positions (all) must be found

Returns:

A list of positions where the string was found

read_all() → List[str]¶

Just a public implementation of self._get_items(). Includes a test for whether a file is bound.

read_index(index: int) → str¶

Returns a string located in the file at a certain position (index)

Parameters:

index – position of the string to be returned

Returns:

the string at the position equal to index

property splitter: str¶
property splitter_check: bool¶
write(text: str, add_splitter: bool = True) → None¶

Writes (overwrites!) a given string (parameter “text”) to the existing (bound) file. The add_splitter argument has to be set False in several cases (for example, in the erase_index method, but usually this should be True. NOTE: if add_splitter is set to False and then append() method is called, the two texts will be considered as one.

Parameters:

  • text – string to be written into the file

  • add_splitter – True is the splitter has to be added after the text. True by default

Returns:
